content: Airline passenger screening in the United States has evolved significantly since the 9/11 attacks, with new technologies and changes in policies overseen by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) created after 9/11 under the Aviation Transportation and Security Act. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) was created after 9/11 under the Aviation Transportation and Security Act (ATSA) to oversee airline passenger screening in the United States. ATSA mandated comprehensive security screening for all passengers and property, but also allowed for trusted traveler programs and the use of technology to expedite screening for certain passengers. The TSA was created after 9/11 to oversee airline passenger screening in the US, allowing for trusted traveler programs and technology to expedite screening.
